Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Minimally Invasive Tissue-Selective Therapy Stapler (TST) for Severe Hemorrhoids

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 141 patients with severe hemorrhoids were randomised into three groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included ages 18-80, grades III-IV hemorrhoids, and no prior hemorrhoid surgery.

Intervention.evidence: minimally invasive TST surgery compared to PPH and EPH techniques

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the clinical efficacy and safety of minimally invasive TST surgery compared to PPH and EPH techniques.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was clinical efficacy, defined as symptom resolution at 3 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using block randomisation with a block size of 6, and allocation was concealed until surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 141 patients with severe hemorrhoids were randomised into three groups: TST (n=47), PPH (n=47), and EPH (n=47).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The TST group demonstrated a higher total effective rate (93.62%) compared to PPH (74.47%) and EPH (72.34%).

Harms.evidence: The complication rate was lower in the TST group (10.64%) compared to PPH (27.66%) and EPH (31.91%).
